posts.name: Benjamin Broudy
posts.cooked: Hello! I used the 3d printed template for the tread for the rev wheels using the black neoprene 1 inch wide from thrifty along with the thrifty aluminum billets. It seems to be a really tight fit, almost too tight of a fit, where I can’t really get the bolts in at all. Is this a common problem, or am I doing something incorrectly? How should I get around this problem. Thank you so much!

There’s a video from TTB that says to remove one of the forks to pop the wheel in. 111 recommended also loosening the other form if needed. 111 also mentioned once installed they fit well and run fine.

posts.name: Benjamin Broudy
posts.cooked: Sorry I think I didn’t explain my issue well, the problem is that the actual tread itself after being cut out on the template isnt fitting around the metal billet wheel properly, it seems to be a bit too tight to the point that I can’t really bolt it on

posts.name: Ryan Dognaux
posts.cooked:
Wondering if the holes might be drilled a little too small too. Tread is pretty finicky - if your 3D printer undersized the template at all, that could throw things off. You should be able to start at one end and by the time you get to the other end and tighten it up, the tread ends should meet. It looks a little short when you cut it but that’s usually not the case once it’s on the wheel.

We have the STEP file for the tread template here too, I would measure the printed template and validate it against your real one.

posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked:
Another potential solution is that according to Rev the template may need to be slightly different depending on the exact tread you used.

Aluminum MAXSwerve Wheels - ION BUILD SYSTEM

link_counts.title: Aluminum MAXSwerve Wheels - ION BUILD SYSTEM

posts.name: Benjamin Broudy
posts.cooked: They seem to be barely a bit short as well as the holes being too close. If I lay it out around the wheel it doesn’t look like the ends can meet up. I measured the template and its exactly 214mm long, which is what the stl is. I drilled it out to 13/64th, maybe I should go 7/32? I could also try maybe printing it scaled up a couple percents. In the video on the page for the billets it looks like the blue tread is less thick than the black neoprene, maybe that’s the reason why?

posts.name: Ryan Dognaux
posts.cooked:
There’s a slight difference in thickness but I did validate the template worked for both in testing -

image 736×977 76.3 KB

image 736×977 76.3 KB

image 736×977 76.3 KB

I don’t think it would hurt to drill out the holes a little more if it’s that close.

You could also cut the strip a little long if you think it’s not going to meet and then trim off the excess.

posts.name: Benjamin Broudy
posts.cooked: Ok, I’ll try that out this afternoon. Thank you so much!

What we did is cut it 1/4 longer than the template, wrapped it around the wheel, cut it till it lined up almost exactly than drilled holes from the left lined up with left side of jig than drill two right holes lined up from right side of jig.

posts.name: Harrison Drake
posts.cooked:
Others have mentioned this, but we are using the TTB wheels with no modifications to the TTB tread drill patterns.

WildStang Robotics Program: Team 111 and 112 Build Blog - 2023 Robot Showcase

This thread is about SDS wheels, but all the same tips/tricks from here apply to the TTB , Rev, printed, custom wheels as well.
